content:
C3-62-0918
March 28, 1962
Mr. R. L. Hirshberg Program Officer United States A.I.D. Mission to China United States Agency for International Development Paoching Road Taipei
Subject: Project Type & Non-Project Type Excess Property
Dear Mr. Hirshberg:
In reply to your letter MC -2923 dated March 20, 1962, we wish to bring forth the following explanations in connection with the acquisition and disposition of Project Type and Non- Project Type Excess Property.
Under the Excess Equipment Project No. 99-471, the con- signors are all U.S. military agencies and the shipping documents received are usually not in details and comprehensive, particularly when shipments are made on military vessels, as in case of normal commercial procurement; hence check of contents and preparation of detailed lists adequate for purposes of allocation and subsequent follow-up are required. On account of this and also because port warehouse is not a practical place for distribution, especially when one shipment as usual and one package in some cases consist of supplies for use of several agencies, custody of the delivered supplies prior to distribution is necessary. Therefore, as agreed upon between Mission, CUSA and other parties concerned, BES was designated as handling agent when this project was started. No change of this arrangement is thought advisable. As the time required for checking and listing varies with the quantities of arrivals and other circumstances, it may not be practical to ask BES to submit detailed lists within 24 hours. Also, it may not be enforceable to set a 3-day limit for recipients to pick up the supplies unless effective and workable measures, if any, can be taken against default. The planner and boring machine referred to in your letter were allocated to KaHB and PWB respectively, both
51. 3. 100×200
國史馆 Academia Historica
454

Mr. R. L. Hirshberg

upon between Mission, CUSA and other parties concerned, BES was

change of this arrangement is thought advisable. As the time
required for checking and listing varies with the quantities of

BES to submit detailed lists within 24 hours. Also, it may not
be enforceable to set a 3-day limit for recipients to pick up the
supplies unless effective and workable measures, if any, can be
taken against default. The planner and boring machine referred to
in your letter were allocated to KaHB and PWB respectively, both

Subject: Project Type & Non-Project Type Excess Property

In reply to your letter MC -2923 dated March 20, 1962, we wish to bring forth the following explanations in connection with the acquisition and disposition of Project Type and Non- Project Type Excess Property.

Under the Excess Equipment Project No. 99-471, the con- signors are all U.S. military agencies and the shipping documents received are usually not in details and comprehensive, particularly when shipments are made on military vessels, as in case of normal commercial procurement; hence check of contents and preparation of detailed lists adequate for purposes of allocation and subsequent follow-up are required. On account of this and also because port warehouse is not a practical place for distribution, especially when one shipment as usual and one package in some cases consist of supplies for use of several agencies, custody of the delivered supplies prior to distribution is necessary.
